parameter 1: The UK version has been cut in four scenes to attain a more lucrative 12A rating. The BBFC suggested to the filmmakers that sight of blood splattering onto a character's face, sight of a character screaming in pain as he burns, sight of a wound being injected and sight of a character self-immolating and burning should all be reduced, in order to avoid a 15 rating.
parameter 2: Available in 52 minute or 1 hour 45 minute full length theatrical release version.
parameter 3: The cut UK theatrical version was also used for the DVD release in the UK. In addition, the same version was also released on DVD in Germany although the uncut version was shown theatrically.
parameter 4: The cut UK theatrical version was also used for the DVD release in the UK. In addition, the same version was also released on DVD in Germany although the uncut version was shown theatrically.
parameter 5: Triple Cross was edited and re-dubbed with new voices and released as Angel of Fury in 1993 by Imperial Video in the USA
parameter 6: The available print has been composed from material lifted from different sources. The opening MGM credits are not the originals but a recreation using the ones from "Big Business" changing the title and certain names. Most of the film itself was lifted from elements used in a Robert Youngson compilation and for this reason the quality of the images notably switches from excellent to terrible, since the rest of the film was probably lifted from worn 16mm prints.
parameter 7: Even though the Finnish videotape is heavily cut (almost all of the violence is cut), there are 2 scenes that are different from the uncut US-DVD. Both of these scenes contain nudity, and have been substituted with less-offensive scenes in the US-DVD. The scenes are Angel Diaz "lending" his mate's girlfriend in the trailer and the scene where Gruner is threating Angel in his apartment with a knife.
parameter 8: The cut UK theatrical version was also used for the DVD release in the UK. In addition, the same version was also released on DVD in Germany although the uncut version was shown theatrically.
parameter 9: The available print has been composed from material lifted from different sources. The opening MGM credits are not the originals but a recreation using the ones from "Big Business" changing the title and certain names. Most of the film itself was lifted from elements used in a Robert Youngson compilation and for this reason the quality of the images notably switches from excellent to terrible, since the rest of the film was probably lifted from worn 16mm prints.
parameter 10: The version that opened in Chicago cut Cagney and O'Brien's scene before the execution, so that audiences were left with the impression that Rocky had turned yellow at his execution. The version shown in Australia and New Zealand went even further, cutting the breakdown scene and the Dead End kid's reaction to it.
parameter 11: The available print has been composed from material lifted from different sources. The opening MGM credits are not the originals but a recreation using the ones from "Big Business" changing the title and certain names. Most of the film itself was lifted from elements used in a Robert Youngson compilation and for this reason the quality of the images notably switches from excellent to terrible, since the rest of the film was probably lifted from worn 16mm prints.
parameter 12: Angel in Exile was re-edited and re-released under the Title Dark Violence in 1954 in the US.
parameter 13: In the French version, instead of 'Geraldo Rivera' (qv) that chuck is going to go after, he says 'Mike Tyson (I)' (qv).
parameter 14: US version titled "Witchcraft '70", narrated by Edmund Purdom, has a different music score and includes additional scenes photographed and directed by Lee Frost (under the name R.L. Frost)
parameter 15: Available in 52 minute or 1 hour 45 minute full length theatrical release version.
parameter 16: US version titled "Witchcraft '70", narrated by Edmund Purdom, has a different music score and includes additional scenes photographed and directed by Lee Frost (under the name R.L. Frost)
parameter 17: Triple Cross was edited and re-dubbed with new voices and released as Angel of Fury in 1993 by Imperial Video in the USA
parameter 18: Some explicit sexual content was edited from the original NC-17 version to be re-rated R.
parameter 19: The Australian 2-disc DVD release is an Extended Version with a running time (PAL format) of 140:17
parameter 20: The version that opened in Chicago cut Cagney and O'Brien's scene before the execution, so that audiences were left with the impression that Rocky had turned yellow at his execution. The version shown in Australia and New Zealand went even further, cutting the breakdown scene and the Dead End kid's reaction to it.
parameter 21: In the re-release version, titled "Angels' Revenge," the structure of the film is radically changed. The womens' attack on the drug processing plant is moved from the middle of the film to the beginning. Halfway through this scene, the picture freezes, and newly recorded voiceover by Jacqueline Cole explains the action and sets up the background of the story. The next hour of the film is made up of the original cut's beginning, now told as a flashback. When the film reaches the point of the womens' raid on the drug plant, the narrative jumps forward, with more voiceover from Cole, and proceeds in an identical fashion to the original cut of the film.
parameter 22: US version titled "Witchcraft '70", narrated by Edmund Purdom, has a different music score and includes additional scenes photographed and directed by Lee Frost (under the name R.L. Frost)
parameter 23: Although rated "not under 18" the German Video-Release, published by Highlight Video, removes some of the violent scenes.
parameter 24: Triple Cross was edited and re-dubbed with new voices and released as Angel of Fury in 1993 by Imperial Video in the USA
parameter 25: The Australian 2-disc DVD release is an Extended Version with a running time (PAL format) of 140:17
parameter 26: The American tv version, presumably in order to make up for time lost in editing the controversial sex scene, added footage that was not included in either the R or Unrated versions. The added footage was mostly made up of flashbacks to the war and other various oddities, and actually helped explain some of the more vague points of the movie.
parameter 27: Available in 52 minute or 1 hour 45 minute full length theatrical release version.
parameter 28: Triple Cross was edited and re-dubbed with new voices and released as Angel of Fury in 1993 by Imperial Video in the USA

parameter 32: The Australian 2-disc DVD release is an Extended Version with a running time (PAL format) of 140:17
parameter 33: Curiously, the sex and violence did not offend the British Board of Film Classification, but a scene of a cockfight did, and 4 secs were duly removed from both cinema and video versions. This cockfight has been seen in a heavily edited US TV version screened in the UK on ITV.
parameter 34: Triple Cross was edited and re-dubbed with new voices and released as Angel of Fury in 1993 by Imperial Video in the USA

The scenes are Angel Diaz "lending" his mate's girlfriend in the trailer and the scene where Gruner is threating Angel in his apartment with a knife.

parameter 37: The American tv version, presumably in order to make up for time lost in editing the controversial sex scene, added footage that was not included in either the R or Unrated versions. The added footage was mostly made up of flashbacks to the war and other various oddities, and actually helped explain some of the more vague points of the movie.
